I read the Amendment process in the Massachusetts constitution. I agree with Kronus that the relevant part is IV. Legislative Action on Proposed
 Constitutional Amendments. From what I gather from the article, I think the question posed is as follows: Does the Massachusetts constitution require the legislature to vote on constitutional amendments that have been appropriately brought before the legislature? I think the Governor has a strong argument for his conclusion.
 
 The key, I think, to this specific situation is that the Amendment is proposed through an initiative petition. Sections 2 (as amended) and 4. Section 2 says that the amendment should be considered by a joint session of the legislature. It further provides:
 
 
...if the two houses fail to agree upon a time for holding any joint session hereby required, or fail to continue the same from time to time until final action has been taken upon all amendments pending, the governor shall call such joint session or continuance thereof.

 
 This provision appears to me to require the legislature to proceed until "final action has been taken upon all amendments pending." In short, it appears the constitution requires the legislature to reach "final action" on constitutional amendments proposed through the initiative petition (via the Governor's request for the continuance of a special session). The question remains, then, is what does "final action" mean? This is where section 4 is relevant.
 
 
Final legislative action in the joint session upon any amendment shall be taken only by call of the yeas and nays, which shall be entered upon the journals of the two houses...

 
 According to section 4, final action can only occur by a roll call vote.
 
 So, in summary:
 
 The legislature is required to consider constitutional amendments in a joint session until final action is taken.
 
 Final action can only occur through a roll call vote.
 
 Adjourning before taking final action on the amendment is therefore acting in violation of the constitution.
 
 An interesting thin to note in this is that the legislature only went into recess, it did not adjourn. From what I have read, there is still one day for them to vote on this measure after the recess.

So, in summary:
 
 The legislature is required to consider constitutional amendments in a joint session until final action is taken.
 
 Final action can only occur through a roll call vote.
 
 Adjourning before taking final action on the amendment is therefore acting in violation of the constitution.
